title: 113_s1624
content: The "VOW to Hire Heroes Extension Act of 2013" extends the Work Opportunity Credit for veterans until December 31, 2017. It also simplifies the certification of veteran status for eligibility. The "VOW to Hire Heroes Extension Act of 2013" amends the Internal Revenue Code to simplify the certification process for qualified veterans seeking treatment. The individual must state, under penalty of perjury, that the information provided is true. Qualified veteran status documentation refers to any documentation from the Department of Defense or National Guard establishing veteran status. Qualified proof of unemployment compensation is also required. The amendment defines "qualified proof of unemployment compensation" as proof of receiving unemployment payments for specific periods. The effective date applies to individuals starting work after the Act's enactment. Credit available against payroll taxes in certain circumstances. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows certain employers, including for-profit employers, to claim a credit against payroll taxes. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code expands eligibility for the tax credit to include for-profit employers. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code expands eligibility for the tax credit to include for-profit employers, under certain conditions. This includes requirements such as the employer not having profits in the preceding 3 taxable years and electing not to have a specific section apply for the taxable year. Additionally, the definition of a qualified veteran for the tax credit is clarified in relation to tax-exempt organizations and for-profit employers. The amendments allocate funds to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund to offset revenue reductions. These funds will be transferred from the general fund to replicate the transfers that would have occurred without the amendments. The changes apply to individuals starting work for an employer after the enactment of the Act. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue, with the Secretary of Labor, must report to Congress on the effectiveness of amendments in increasing veteran employment. The report will include a survey to determine how many veterans are hired by employers claiming certain credits under the Internal Revenue Code. The Secretary of the Treasury will pay possessions of the United States for losses due to tax system amendments. Payments will be based on information provided by the respective governments. The Act provides for payments to possessions of the United States for tax system amendments. Possessions must show equivalent income tax benefits to receive the credit allowed against United States income taxes. The Act allows tax credits against United States income taxes for possessions of the United States that demonstrate equivalent income tax benefits. Possessions include American Samoa, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands. The Act provides tax credits for possessions of the United States based on income tax laws, treating payments as refunds under section 1324(b)(2) of title 31, United States Code.
